summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of a motion to dismiss Counts One through Four of the superseding indictment as time-barred. The document argues that the charges, based on alleged conduct from 1994-1997, are barred by the five-year statute of limitations and that the government's reliance on a 2003 amendment extending the limitations period for child abuse offenses is improper because it should not apply retroactively and does not cover the Mann Act violations she is charged with.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, charged with conspiracy and substantive violations of the Mann Act related to the transportation of minors for illegal sexual activity with Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual with whom Minor Victim-1 was intended to engage in sex acts, according to the indictment's allegations cited in the memorandum.

persons.context: Lead attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, a partner at Cohen & Gresser LLP, who signed the memorandum.

connections.description: The indictment alleges Maxwell conspired to transport and entice minors to travel to engage in sex acts with Epstein.
Cohen is listed as a lead defense attorney representing Maxwell in this motion.

Pagliuca is a defense attorney representing Maxwell.
Menninger is a defense attorney representing Maxwell.

events.title: Alleged Mann Act Violations
events.description: The period during which Ghislaine Maxwell is alleged to have conspired and committed offenses involving the transportation and enticement of minors (Minor Victim-1) across state lines for illegal sexual activity with Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Enactment of PROTECT Act Amendment
events.description: Congress amended 18 U.S.C. § 3283 to extend the statute of limitations for offenses involving child sexual abuse, kidnapping, or physical abuse to 'during the life of the child.'

events.title: Return of Superseding Indictment
events.description: The government returned the superseding indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell in July 2020, charging her with offenses alleged to have occurred in the mid-1990s.

events.title: Filing of Motion to Dismiss
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team filed this memorandum in support of a motion to dismiss Counts One through Four of the indictment as time-barred.

locations: 33 West 19th Street - 4th Floor, New York, NY 10011
keyFacts: The defense argues the charges (Counts 1-4) from 1994-1997 are time-barred by the general 5-year statute of limitations (18 U.S.C. § 3282).

The defense contends the 2003 amendment to 18 U.S.C. § 3283 (extending the limitations period for child abuse offenses) should not apply retroactively to pre-2003 conduct, citing legislative history where Congress rejected a retroactivity provision.

The defense argues that even if the 2003 amendment applied, § 3283 does not cover the charged Mann Act offenses (18 U.S.C. §§ 2422, 2423) because they do not 'necessarily entail' the sexual/physical abuse or kidnapping of a child as an element of the crime.

The memorandum references three accusers, including 'Minor Victim-1' and 'Minor Victim-3', the latter of whom turned 25 in March 2002, making charges related to her time-barred even before the 2003 amendment.
The filing is a strategic legal argument focusing on statutory interpretation and the presumption against retroactivity, not a factual rebuttal of the underlying allegations.
